Situation1: All household chores must be coordinated because relatives are visiting, and the home needs to be fully presentable.
Situation2: The taxi driver ensures the cab remains neat and hygienic.
Story: I woke up to the sound of my phone buzzing—my spouse reminding me that her parents would arrive in the evening. The house was a mess, and she expected me to help scrub the floors, dust the shelves, and make everything spotless. I promised I’d be home early to help, but as I grabbed my keys, another message popped up: the taxi company was short-staffed, and they needed me to cover an extra shift. My cab was due for a deep clean, and I couldn’t risk a bad review from a passenger if it wasn’t immaculate. I could feel the pressure mounting—my spouse counting on me to share the load at home, my boss and passengers expecting me to keep my car pristine and be available. I stared at the cleaning supplies in the hallway, then at my cab keys in my hand, torn between two worlds, both demanding more than I felt I could give.
